channel.title: 2 more questions (noob java questions)
channel.description:
Well I'm learning my tutorials from thenewboston and I think I may have zoned out on these parts
When i'm going to write [b]i[b]mport java.util.Scanner;[/b][/b] Does the word have to be scanner or can I use another word?
Also what does public static void main(string args[]){ mean?
Again I may have zoned out on these parts so sorry for asking a stupid question :/.

item.title: 2 more questions (noob java questions)

Wow ty. Now i really get it

item.title: 2 more questions (noob java questions)
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“IcyyEffect, post:1, topic:456164”]Well I’m learning my tutorials from thenewboston and I think I may have zoned out on these parts

When i’m going to write
import java.util.Scanner;
Does the word have to be scanner or can I use another word?

Also what does public static void main(string args[]){ mean?

Again I may have zoned out on these parts so sorry for asking a stupid question :/.[/quote]
Scanner refers to the class you’re importing (which is basically saying that java.util.Scanner’s namespace is also apart of your class’s namespace). So, if you’re wanting to use Scanner (which is commonly use for user input), then it must be scanner.

public static void main(String[] args), better known as the main method, is an entry point to your application from the runtime environment. This means, when you execute your application, this will be the method that gets executed. To break the components of the method declaration down:

public: indicates public access rights to the member. in terms of methods, it means that any internal and external member can reference it.

static: indicates that the member is only allocated once, even if there’s multiple instances of the object with in memory.

main: is the name of the method.

String[] args: is the argument for the method. in this case, it’s an array of Strings called ‘args’. in the main method, args is filled with the command-line arguments that are given upon execution. (ex: java myApp test -> args[0] is “test”)

Read full topic

item.title: 2 more questions (noob java questions)
item.dc:creator: @dclawed dclawed
item.description:
@dclawed wrote:

Public means anyone in the programme can access it, you can add other peoples packages into your project, if you use private you cant add anyone elses project, there are private/protected as well which you will learn later on in Java, The string args is used to access command-line arguments. main is is the name of the method, I learnt this today, also if you dont know what they mean, there your really going to find Java hard, and to learn to make programmes will take you ages, I have looked at thenewboston as well, it shows tutorials etc. static is a keyword and denotes that any other class, you should learn all the keywords, you can`t use them in the class or main.

Your welcome
Dclawed

Read full topic

item.title: 2 more questions (noob java questions)
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“IcyyEffect, post:1, topic:456164”]Well I’m learning my tutorials from thenewboston and I think I may have zoned out on these parts

When i’m going to write
import java.util.Scanner;
Does the word have to be scanner or can I use another word?

Also what does public static void main(string args[]){ mean?

Again I may have zoned out on these parts so sorry for asking a stupid question :/.[/quote]

I haven’t touched on java in ages, and even when I did I was horribly shit.

There’s other ways of calling user input than the scanner, but it can’t just be a random word. Also, public static void main(string args[]) { is your main method afaik.

Read full topic
